A brief address by university
President, Dr. Lowell J. Reed, was
the highlight of the freshman
orientation banquet held Monday
evening in Levering Hall.
The dinner, part of the orientation program, was attended by
several other notables from various divisions of the university.
Dr. Walter Boyer, Professor of
Engineering, was toastCivil
present
master.
were
Others
Trustee John Sherwood; Vice
President of the Alumni Association, Eli Frank, Jr.; speaking in
the stead of the president, Dr.

Fitzgerald Duney; Provost of the
school, Stuart McCauley; and Dr.
Sidney Painter, representing the
faculty of the Hopkins.
In his speech President Reed
explained the spirit of the university and declared the university
to be the oldest part of our culture. The President also remarked that the university is composed
of an aggregation of scholars
which exists because we have men
dedicated to the school.
He went on to state that the
long life of such an institution
can be ascribed to the steady in-

flux of young people which keeps
the spirit of the university alive.
Dr. Reed went, on to add at this
point that if necessary he could
successfully run the school without a faculty but not without a
student body.
In conclusion President -Reed
stressed the fact that this university spirit manifests itself in
an air of independent thinking,
but that it was for each student
to find how to best use this air of
independence. Each must look
things over conscientiously and
decide wisely, intelligently and

with individuality how to favorably assert his newly acquired independence.
A second speaker, Dr. Sidney_
Painter, advised the new students
to be conscientious in their studies and if help was needed, to
consult the professor concerned,
because in a university the faculty
does not lie awake nights worrying about the problems the students might have in their studies.
He went on to say, however, that
the 'faculty members would always be willing to aid the students.

A Freshman's Viewpoint ...
The following is the winning entry in an editorial contest
that was open to all freshmen. While we do not necessarily concur
with the view, we note with interest that the writer has already
come in contact with the elusive nature of the spirit of the
Hopkins. We viewed the results of the contest with admiration,
for as Hopkins neophytes we could not have been so positive.
We, the men o'f the Freshman Class, are disappointed. We
find that we cannot easily be an integral part of that official
and dramatic name, The Class of '58. And why this condition?
As new members of the undergraduate community, we seek to
become affiliated with a group. But which group The•"campus
veterans" have all the answers. "Simply join a club, my boy,"
or "Just enter a social fraternity.",From other sages we hear
"No class distinction—you're one of us.",To be sure, all of
these suggestions have some merit, but we know we're not seniors,
and inside of us we seek to belong to a group larger than a
club or social fraternity.
Ideally, our group membership would be with The Hopkins.
But The Hopkins is too all-encompassing, too limitless, too vague.
We shall feel that closeness in later years. We want the present.
We submit that there is nothing wrong with a strong
class organization. Individual efforts could then be united
at a practical level, instead of being lost in the gigantic over-all
picture. Each freshman, indeed each undergraduate, would then
know that he and his group were making a definite,• visible contribution to The University. Let's try it!
We, the Class of 1958, 333 strong, shall inexorably follow
the great ideals and principles so strongly established by our
predecessors. But may it be said of us in retrospect, "They did
not follow divided; rather they led united."

approximately

Lew Sank and Ray Garman, cochairmen of the Weekend, were

president, members of the faculty,
and Dr. Chester L. Wickwire,

Those attending left Levering
Hall approximately 12:00 noon

chartered buses. They arrived at
camp
forty-five minutes later.

John Bridgers, Hopkins' head Football coach, begins his

team is definitely stronger than last years, but the reserves are
awfully weak" is the way Bridgers describes the team after
observing pre-season practice.
Even though Bridgers has lost 10 of 13 lettermen from last
year's squad, he feels that the combination of letterman, returnees,
men from last year's Freshman squad, and new-comers to
Hopkins football will give him a better team than last season.

him last year will no longer be acute. Bridgers uses the
Tennessee style single wing which
employes a balanced line with the
backfield shifting to the left or
the right.

A brief address by university
President, Dr. Lowell J. Reed, was
the highlight of the freshman
orientation banquet held Monday
evening in Levering Hall.
The dinner, part of the orientation program, was attended by
several other notables from various divisions of the university.
Dr. Walter Boyer, Professor of
Engineering, was toastCivil
present
master.

Others
Trustee John Sherwood; Vice
President of the Alumni Association, Eli Frank, Jr.; speaking in
the stead of the president, Dr.

Fitzgerald Duney; Provost of the
school, Stuart McCauley; and Dr.
Sidney Painter, representing the
faculty of the Hopkins.
In his speech President Reed
explained the spirit of the university and declared the university
to be the oldest part of our culture. The President also remarked that the university is composed
of an aggregation of scholars
which exists because we have men
dedicated to the school.
He went on to state that the
long life of such an institution
can be ascribed to the steady in-

flux of young people which keeps
the spirit of the university alive.
Dr. Reed went, on to add at this
point that if necessary he could
successfully run the school without a faculty but not without a
student body.
In conclusion President -Reed
stressed the fact that this university spirit manifests itself in
an air of independent thinking,
but that it was for each student
to find how to best use this air of
independence. Each must look
things over conscientiously and
decide wisely, intelligently and

with individuality how to favorably assert his newly acquired independence.
A second speaker, Dr. Sidney_
Painter, advised the new students
to be conscientious in their studies and if help was needed, to
consult the professor concerned,
because in a university the faculty
does not lie awake nights worrying about the problems the students might have in their studies.
He went on to say, however, that
the 'faculty members would always be willing to aid the students.

A Freshman's Viewpoint ...
The following is the winning entry in an editorial contest
that was open to all freshmen. While we do not necessarily concur
with the view, we note with interest that the writer has already
come in contact with the elusive nature of the spirit of the
Hopkins. We viewed the results of the contest with admiration,
for as Hopkins neophytes we could not have been so positive.
We, the men o'f the Freshman Class, are disappointed. We
find that we cannot easily be an integral part of that official
and dramatic name, The Class of '58. And why this condition?
As new members of the undergraduate community, we seek to
become affiliated with a group. But which group The•"campus
veterans" have all the answers. "Simply join a club, my boy,"
or "Just enter a social fraternity.",From other sages we hear
"No class distinction—you're one of us.",To be sure, all of
these suggestions have some merit, but we know we're not seniors,
and inside of us we seek to belong to a group larger than a
club or social fraternity.
Ideally, our group membership would be with The Hopkins.
But The Hopkins is too all-encompassing, too limitless, too vague.
We shall feel that closeness in later years. We want the present.
We submit that there is nothing wrong with a strong
class organization. Individual efforts could then be united
at a practical level, instead of being lost in the gigantic over-all
picture. Each freshman, indeed each undergraduate, would then
know that he and his group were making a definite,• visible contribution to The University. Let's try it!
We, the Class of 1958, 333 strong, shall inexorably follow
the great ideals and principles so strongly established by our
predecessors. But may it be said of us in retrospect, "They did
not follow divided; rather they led united."

Freshman Camp
More than 225 freshmen, student leaders, and faculty members
participated in the "Y"-sponsored
Freshman

Weekend.

Sponsored

by the Hopkins YMCA, the affair
enjoyed its greatest attendance to
date, and marked an increase of
approximately

100

participants

over last year's Weekend and an
Increase of approximately 200 over
the 1952 Weekend.
Lew Sank and Ray Garman, cochairmen of the Weekend, were
assisted by a staff of leaders including Peter Bower, "Y" chapter
president, members of the faculty,
and Dr. Chester L. Wickwire,
Executive Secretary of the Hopkins "Y."
Those attending left Levering
Hall approximately 12:00 noon
on Saturday, September 25, in
chartered buses. They arrived at
camp
forty-five minutes later.
c
The ensuing program included
softball, football, volleyball, horseshoes, swimming, "bull-sessions,"
a hot-dog roast, faculty and student entertainment, and discussion groups.
The athletic program was highlighted by a faculty softball victory over the sturients by a onerun margin, 5-4.
Saturday evening a variety show
was presented by members of the
various student&
faculty and
Highlighting the entertainment
was a magic exhibition, a faculty
quartette, and community singing.
Lynn Poole, director of public
relations at Hopkins took pietures at the pool and other activities, from which he expects te
make a 30 minute film of the
goings on.
Sunday services for Jewish,
Catholic, and Protestant students
were held in the morning.

FRED SMITH

1954 Varsity football squad plays host to Franklin and
Marshall of Lancaster, Pennsylvania tomorrow at two p.m. in the
opener for b"othi teams.
John Bridgers, Hopkins' head Football coach, begins his
sec'ond season at the helm with the hope of avenging last year's
47-13 pasting handed JHU at the hands of the invaders."The first
team is definitely stronger than last years, but the reserves are
awfully weak" is the way Bridgers describes the team after
observing pre-season practice.
Even though Bridgers has lost 10 of 13 lettermen from last
year's squad, he feels that the combination of letterman, returnees,
men from last year's Freshman squad, and new-comers to
Hopkins football will give him a better team than last season.
The problem of installing anew system which confronted
him last year will no longer be acute. Bridgers uses the
Tennessee style single wing which
employes a balanced line with the
backfield shifting to the left or
the right.
The starting line-up will not
present too many familiar faces
as only four of the starters were
members of last year's varsity
squad. They are lettermen Buzz
Williams and Dick Watts, cocaptains, at right tackle and blocking back, respectively; letterman
John Steers, at tail back; and returnee Al Whately, at left end.
Seven Newcomers Start
The rest of the starting line-up
comes from men out for the first
time or up from the Freshman
squad of last year. Three of the
seven sophomores on the squad
are listed as starters. They are
Don Gallagher, center; Ken - McJOHN BRIDGERS
Graw, left guard; and Sam Wright,
right guard. Three transferees—
Jim Dunn, right end; Barrie Wood,
wingback and fastest man on the
squad; and Jack Lawrence, fullback—and John Forte, playing his
first year of college ball, complete
the starting line-up.
